title: The remarkable rise of Nick Cotric
text:
Jarrod Croker gives Nick Cotric vote of confidence to replace departing Raiders winger Edrick Lee February 23, 2017 3:47pm @glover_benny Source: FOX SPORTS CANBERRA skipper Jarrod Croker has given teenage gun Nick Cotric a huge vote of confidence, with the young gun all of a sudden in line to become the Raiders’ first choice left winger. 
The boom centre only turned 18 in November but his star has risen rapidly since joining the first grade squad for pre-season. 
Tipped to replace the injured Croker for Canberra’s round one trip to North Queensland, Cotric now finds himself in a position to secure a spot outside his mentor for the rest of the season, after the Raiders today released Edrick Lee to take up a two year deal with the Sharks . 
With Croker not due back from a knee injury until round four at the earliest, Canberra’s left edge has gone from one of its biggest strengths to its biggest question mark. 
Prior to the release of Lee, Cotric had firmed to win the battle with Jordan Turner for Croker’s left centre position but the rangy winger’s exit will force a rethink from Ricky Stuart. 
With Kato Ottio still recovering from a torn ACL, Croker said Brent Naden and Eddie Aiono would also be in the mix. 
Stuart is also understood to be considering shifting one of his back-rowers into a makeshift left centre role until Croker returns. 
More likely is that the opening will gift Cotric an opportunity, either at centre or wing, and Croker is confident the kid touted ‘the next big thing;’ is up to it. 
“He’s coming along well, he’s a big kid, he’s certainly got the size there,” Croker told foxsports.com.au . Nick Cotric pops a pass for the Australian Schoolboys. Source: News Corp Australia 
“He’s pretty raw, he’s only sort of played a season of 20s. 
“If he gets the nod, he’s ready to go. He’s big enough, he’s powerful enough and he’s got the players around him to help him out out there. 
“Whether he’s there or Jordan Turner or someone else, I’m not sure, but if he gets the nod, he’ll be ready to go.” 
Croker said he had been working closely on Cotric’s development during the pre-season, with the teenager’s power and confidence his stand out qualities. 
Despite his rapid rise and the big expectations starting to mount on him, Croker said his protege wasn’t getting ahead of himself. 
“I’ve been doing a lot with Nick over the preseason to try to calm him down. He’s a good kid, he wants to play and he wants to learn,” Croker said. 
“The more he learns, the more he listens, the harder he tries, he’s going to go well. 
“He’s really confident, you’ve got to be these days. 
“He’s confident, he’s a great young kid, he’s polite, he’s a well mannered kid, so I hope whenever he does get his chance he takes it with both hands.” 
Speaking to The Daily Telegraph in the lead up to Lee’s release, coach Stuart admitted he felt let down by the salary cap system and its propensity to push out long-serving players. 
Lee, 24, and 28-year-old Fensom, who looks set for an imminent switch to the Cowboys, have spent their whole careers in green, making the call to let them go a tough one. 
“It is the hardest thing I have had to do as coach of the Raiders, sitting both these men down and having to talk to them about their futures,” Stuart said. 
“I have felt uncomfortable about it for many months and I still don’t feel comfortable today because they are two mates. 
“And I can tell you it is something the players here struggle to understand also, especially when you are building a culture at a club. NRL 2017 officially underway 2:59 
“The players don’t want to lose their mates, and neither do the fans. I totally understand that because that is exactly how I feel. But it is the reality of the salary cap as it is.” 
Croker has played his whole career with Fensom, winning an under 20s competition with the discarded back-rower, and he admitted it would be a tough pill to swallow to lose him from the squad. 
“Fenno and I won the under 20s together nine or 10 years ago. He’s been a lifelong friend of mine, a very close mate so it would be sad to lose him,” Croker said. 
“Edrick’s the same, Edrick and I have played alongside each other on the field for the last four or five years now. 
“If that’s the case and I know it’s football and it’s the way it is sometimes, but it’s extremely disappointing. 
“You don’t want to have to let club greats and great mates like that go but sometimes unfortunately that’s the way it is.”
